context: Stephen Hawking in particular has addressed a connection between time and <a0_0><b5_0><b10_0>the Big Bang<b10_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/>. In <a1_0><b6_0><b11_0>A Brief History of Time<b11_0/><a1_0/> and elsewhere<b6_0/>, Hawking says that even if time did not begin with the Big Bang and there were another time frame before the Big Bang, no information from events then would be accessible to us, and <b13_0>nothing that happened then<b13_0/> would have any effect upon the present time-frame. Upon occasion, Hawking has stated that <a2_0>time<a2_0/> actually began with <b14_0>the Big Bang<b14_0/>, and that questions about what happened before the Big Bang are <a3_0><b7_0>meaningless<b7_0/><a3_0/>. This less-nuanced, but commonly repeated formulation has received criticisms from philosophers such as <a4_0><b9_0><b12_0>Aristotelian<b9_0/> philosopher <b8_0>Mortimer J. Adler<b12_0/><b8_0/><a4_0/>.
